comments.commentBody: If the president elect, or the president, makes an important claim, of course the onus is on him to substantiate it.  If you believe election officials should take pains to ensure that those who vote are citizens and properly registered, perhaps you should look into whether or not they actually do, before implying that they don't, and offering a discriminatory remedy.

Trump enjoys adulation and attention far more than he cares about the truth. In his too vivid imagination, it's impossible, literally impossible that he lost the popular vote to Hillary Clinton. And to lose to a 'woman', it's unthinkable in his universe.

Meanwhile his minions spin tall tales, like Bill O' Reilly tonight issuing the proclamation that it could have happened just this way, that Bill's research team - one of the finest! - went to California and found out just how easy it is easy for 'illegals' to become registered and to vote. It was easy to imagine Bill with his imaginary Ben Franklin glasses, peering deeply into the faces of his television audience. The lie must be kept alive!

Meanwhile on planet earth, our president elect has been unremittingly the butt of more jokes than likely any president elect in American history, not only here but around the world.

We await a deluge of Pinocchio cartoons, interposed with The Donald's face. With his massively inflated egoistic head, now barely able to pass through normal doorways, Don will have to go into rooms now always face first, as his nose will preclude him from entering any other way.

I believe it is missing the point to suggest that Trump's problem is vanity and ego.
I believe something much more sinister is at play inside of his problematic personality. What that sinister aspect consists of remains to be uncovered.

Tim,

You said, " ... Don will have to go into rooms now always face first ..."

And that will cause even more problems because he will have to pause to make a choice of WHICH ONE to enter with!

"And to lose to a 'woman', it's unthinkable in his universe."

Especially since his only idea of a winning woman is a not-yet-dressed Miss Universe.
Correction: "Sago" mine disaster.

Sanctuary is a meaningless term and it is not the job of cities to proactively seek out those here illegally. That said, many of us in the northwest despise the perversion of language that attempts to conflate legal with illegal immigration. Those who made decisions to come illegally do not earn my sympathy or respect. Their minor children do and perhaps might be allowed to stay if they are 'dreamers' while sending their parents back, as most of these are at an age of self-sufficiency.
And most perversely, we insult the great country of Mexico, with 122 million people, with education, opportunity and economic growth and diversity. Suggesting that one can't be happy or successful there is non-sensical and chauvinistic. Sure there are bad spots there and tough circumstances, but likewise many places in the US are desperate.
We must enforce our laws, and change immigration criteria to one based upon admitting those who are contributors. No more family preferences for adult siblings, elderly parents, cousins and the like. And let's put an end to birthright citizenship, which is something perhaps 30 countries including the US offer. One should not be able to show up as a tourist or a non-resident, deliver a child who is conferred this precious benefit. My grandson was born in South Africa while his parents were working there and had no such right. I did not vote for him, but this is a position of his that I and many other 'liberals, including Times readers, heartily support.

Besides being totally immoral, torture is ineffective.
Consider the "ticking bomb " scenario.
There is a ticking bomb somewhere and person X to be tortured knows where that bomb is located.
Leave aside for the moment the real question as to how the torturers know the bomb exists.
X is tortured. To stop the torture X gives information. But as John McCain [who was tortured unlike Trump who was not] has stated the information X gives is unreliable and often false.
False information then DELAYS finding this ticking bomb.
So besides being immoral torture is ineffective and should continue to be banned.

As someone who, unlike most of you, who has been tortured I can state that most of the information you get from that is shacky at best.
And to those who say there is little lasting effect, please explain to me why I still wake up in the middle of the night thinking I am drowning.

Those who torture simply do not care about the effects on those tortured.
They believe that the need for information justifies any means.
In addition there are sadistic people who enjoy inflicting pain on others.
On all grounds , moral and practical, torture must be banned.

Have you considered that he might be seriously mentally ill? I'm not a professional, but have family members who suffer from delusions.

“Delusional disorder, previously called paranoid disorder, is a type of serious mental illness called a "psychosis" in which a person cannot tell what is real from what is imagined. The main feature of this disorder is the presence of delusions, unshakable beliefs in something untrue or not based on reality.”

Nate Cohn does a good job when he sticks to the data. Less so when he resorts to marginalia and innuendo.

I agree with Cohn's view that it is unlikely that serious voting irregularities occurred in the 2016 presidential race.

That said, Cohn's slap at Bernie Sanders and Jill Stein is gratuitous and unwarranted.
-The Sanders campaign never alleged voting irregularities, and accepted its defeat in the primaries. Bernie Sanders campaigned hard for Hillary Clinton during the general election campaign.
-The Jill Stein recount is a public service, given the National Security Agency's view that Russia worked actively to undermine the integrity of the 2016 election.

I donated to the Jill Stein recount effort to ensure that the reported 2016 tallies were accurate. The intent is not to unfairly flip the election, but to verify or correct reported results as needed. There is no downside to conducting a recount to verify the results of the 2016 election.

The larger point that needs to be made about this recount is that the professionals who initially brought their concerns to the Clinton campaign, which chose NOT to act on those concerns until the Stein campaign forced the issue, were apparently alarmed that Hillary's vote in several swing states was roughly 7% less than expected in districts where voting machines that lacked a paper trail were used. This could be nothing more than coincidence.

Unfortunately, there is no way to recount a vote cast in a machine that produces no paper trail. The simple fact that so many machines lack that trail creates a plausible reason for doubt in the validity of the process.

Perhaps in 2002 and 2003 no one could imagine Russian or Chinese agents attempting to manipulate an American election; but in 2016, we can readily imagine such a thing.

If a paper trail existed, all reasonable suspicions could be dispelled; but without that paper trail, suspicion is inevitable and perhaps even warranted.

To Matthew and Peg.
The better approach to this problematic situation would be:
An examination of the system analysis and the software developed to implement the compilation of voting results.
The system should be thoroughly examined for malware and malicious intent.
Just remember that anything can be hacked.

Modifying numbers to meet predetermined outcomes is certainly possible.
Begin an examination of 4 or 5 important states and move on from there.

Another question:
Where was the system and the software developed and what specific entities where involved in the effort.
Were there back doors built into the software that could be utilized to hack the voting results.
Let us hope that somewhere, someone is investigating these possibilities.

Pursuing a different tack -- It is obvious that Trump intends to use the presidency  for his all-important goal of personal enrichment.  Look at his many conflicts of interest!  The Constitution specifically states that the Presidency shall not be used for emoluments resulting from foreign interests.  Under the Constitution, the electoral college must invalidate his candidacy.
Martin, everyday I wake up like I have a weight lifted off my shoulders.

After my third espresso, I open my eyes.

Sister and her husband left today. It's been a busy week, but a fun start to my "busy season." 27 for Thanksgiving is a warm-up for the 50-75 at New Year's in Seattle, which is almost here.
Morning, Joe.  Are you going to [] Fair?  Parsley, Sage, Rosemary, and Thyme.
I think it's meant to be symbolic.  They are literally stripped of everything and at the mercy of their human masters.

I agree that the math doesn't compute for a reversal.

But wonks like you and Nate Silver shouldn't be so smug. The polls were wrong and you guys drank the pollsters' KoolAid. Nor did any election expert predict that Russia would hack the Clinton campaign and the DNC, reason enough for the USG to go on alert against Russian hacking of the ballot.

The virtue of having a recount far outweighs the likelihood (there are no absolute certainties here) that recounts will not alter the results in any of the three states. Recounts will restore voter confidence, now shaken, that we can rely on the Presidential vote to be counted honestly.

Trump's big lie about 3 million illegal voters (all Mexican rapists?) apparently is based on white nationalist inventions. It is speculative but Trump probably said this nonsense in order to distract media attention from 1) his numerous conflicts of interest and 2) the qualifications or lack thereof of his appointments to date. If so, he succeeded.

The clear and present danger in Trump's remarks is that they signal a Republican drive to disenfranchise in the 2018 electoral cycle large numbers of Hispanics and blacks through well honed techniques of voter suppression, sanctified by a Jeff Sessions Justice Department and, probably, by a Supreme Court made tame by new Trump appointments.
Could it be because Latin America consists of many more countries than Mexico?  Look at a map and seek out Central and South America.
Or we could have just paid each president and SoS for working 24/7. Overtime would have been appreciated, I'm sure.
Are you concerned about the Canadian border? We get just as many illegals through that border. For some reason, no one seems to care.

Agree that there is a great deal of hypocrisy in largely conservative growers flaunting the law. Part of this process should be prosecution of those who don't use e-verify like my business does on all hires, including those who visibly are highly unlikely to be illegal. We will survive a rise in food prices due to greater labor costs. Or we can resume a guest worker program, where the worker is permitted, on a limited basis, without their family, to do a job. All businesses must follow the law on only hiring legal workers.
Why do you say priority? And why are law-abiding citizens seeking entry to their own country?

Yeah, history will be the ultimately judge in the end. It was once legal to own slaves but many were against it. Just because something is legal today doesn't make it right or perceived as legal in the future. It is every person's responsibility in this world to fight against unjust actions. Blanket statements about immigration have no meaning. Each individual case is unique.

People do break laws, and there are penalties for them. People who have been here for a long period and have not broken any other laws could be allowed to stay paying a fine, and paying back taxes if they haven't done so. It is not a big deal. Deportation is an extreme response IMO. Even when people kill other people, the response isn't always a death penalty.

Besides, I think the US is stronger because of its immigrants, both legal and lapsed/illegal.

I'm not a religious, white-supremacist, or alt-right freak. I am a staunch supporter of a mutualized health care system that guarantees quality health care to every citizen, even those who can't afford it; and my position on abortion is that it's no one's decision to make other than the woman concerned. With regards to the corporate world, I think this country's laws and policies should be shaped in the interest of its people over that of its business lobbies. On many fronts, I side with Liberals, and in some cases, with Socialists.
But with regards to Illegal Immigration, I believe common sense dictates that no wide-ranging social advancement is sustainable if it's open to abuse by unlimited numbers of Illegal Aliens. Furthermore, the Middle Class needs to be re-empowered; and drowning the job market with Illegals and bogus HB visas runs counter to any improvement in the Middle Class's fate.
The current refusal to enforce laws, and to simply regulate immigration, serves to alienate further the weakest and poorest among our own underclass: namely Blacks to a large extent, and lower-class Whites. The same ones Liberals, and incidentally Social Justice Warrior mayors of sanctuary cities pretend to care about.

I hate that homeless shelters, the elderly, and children would have to suffer from the lack of funds should a backlash occur, but if that's what it takes to expose the hypocrisy of "sanctuary cities" and force those responsible to set their priorities straight, so be it.

The viable path to citizenship is to go back to their home country and apply legally after going to the back of the line.  You don't tolerate people cutting in front of you at the Movies so why tolerate violators of our immigration laws?

Well, I think immigrants (both legal and illegal) add to the welfare of the country overall than most other groups, perhaps all of them in fact. The "immigrant mentality" is one of the greatest things about the US. And accepting immigrants (legal and illegal) along the lines of what is inscribed at the base of the Statue of Liberty is a way to make amends for the genocide that was visited upon the previous peoples that lived here.
Most US voters who did vote did so for Clinton. Most people also did not vote for Trump.

IT goes both ways. The liberal cities don't have to subsidise the nonliberal areas of the country, which is what it is currently.  It's the same with marijuana also, though that has progressed a bit more.  Progressives are on the right arc of history.

Sanctuary city mayors vowing to defy federal law have given President-elect Trump a gift.  These belligerent mayors are reinforcing for millions why they were wise to have voted for Trump.  We could have endured more years wherein the interests of those who are not in this country legally are promoted over the interests of both citizens and applicants for legal immigration.  We might have had to put up with more years of so-called "undocumented immigrants" demanding their imagined rights in a country that owes them nothing but nevertheless goes to unbelievable expense to educate them, give them free healthcare, reward them with in state tuition, and treat them to an alphabet soup of local and state welfare benefits.  Instead, we're going to finally put a stop to the open borders madness that both parties have promoted.

Pure newspeak, straight out of a reverse 1984. A person who commits a felony is a felon. Immigrants, of course, can be illegal. And the list can go on.
People who insist on ramming this claptrap down our throats should just simply admit that they support uncontrolled borders, and be done with it.

So to confirm, millions of people who breached American law and stayed in the country illegally will be protected by cities in opposition to the duly elected government? The US is a sovereign nation that believes in the rule of law isn't it?
